captions.caption:
Our work explores and presents
workers' ideas and imaginaries

on how to redesign algorithmic
work features to support their

well-being. Workers offered
realistic and

stakeholder-inclusive solutions
that mutually align their

interests with platform business
needs, such as allowing

information translucency over
transparency to address

information asymmetries or
suggesting configurable

incentives that platforms can
then match to their own
compensation models.

Second, in discussing their
fairness perceptions of

platforms, workers identified
specific processes where

inequities exist. These can be
avenues that HCI and human

centered data science
researchers can look to for
supporting workers.

And finally, our findings offer
nuanced understandings of how

workers view algorithmic
management, fairness

perceptions, and platform impact
on well-being. We contribute to

a growing understanding of the
impact of algorithmic management

on worker well-being, sharing
the ways that workers imagined

technology design that centers
their well-being and work
preferences.

One of the ways participants
viewed for ameliorating this was

through a platform or forum for
collective information sharing

that could serve for
investigative or advocacy

purposes. P17 illustrates here
one way that collective

information or data sharing can
assist drivers by supporting

them to investigate perceived
inequalities. P17 has a

suspicion that Quest promotions
become harder to accomplish as

drivers get closer to completing
it, and imagines how they can

leverage aggregated driver data
to investigate.

Participants envision how
collective auditing or

collective information sharing
can allow them to advocate for

worker rights by drawing out
findings such as this, or even

supporting larger policy changes
to support workers.

Finally, drivers discuss how
inherently their work isolates

them from their peers and from
their platforms. "Our

communication network is pretty
flimsy and non-existent. And so

we don't really have the
strength in numbers that you see

in a lot of workplaces because
we're so isolated." This

encapsulates the lack of formal
ways to collaborate with one

another or receive support from
the platform.

In their solutions, participants
displayed an awareness for the

complexities of why platforms
may not want to reveal all of

the ride request information.
For example, P6 recognizes that

destination can be used to
discriminate against riders and

not wanting to exacerbate that
problem, suggests platforms

provide translucency such as
direction or distance of a

destination rather than the
exact destination to still

support drivers protecting their
well-being.
determine compensation.

The third problem participants
identified was uneven

information access by the
platform. For example, P3 says

"They definitely treat it like
it's a perk, when it's kind of a

necessity." P3 is explaining
that platforms unfairly withhold

information such as the rider's
final destination, which drivers

often use as clues about their
safety situation.

One of the solutions that
drivers suggested for addressing

unfair differentials on the apps
revolved around flexible

incentive configurations.
Drivers imagined configuring

incentive offers they received,
whether by switching between

Quest offers or implementing
incremental payouts for ride

achievements, in order to
support a healthier well-being.

One driver also suggested being
able to customize incentives,

alluding to a pizza metaphor,
where he could choose rewards

criteria like pizza toppings
that apps like Uber could then

weight and rank against their
own demand forecasting to
determine compensation.

plan more, avoid driving while
sleep-deprived, and encourage a
work life balance.

Gamification was brought up
frequently as a source of

unfairness drivers faced on
platforms. Those refers to

methods platforms use to
encourage drivers to drive more.

"Quest" is a terminology
specifically used by Uber where

the platform will offer
different drivers different,

unequal driving bonuses. In the
quote here, P11 explains that

Quests are presented to drivers
inconsistently and based on

factors outside of their
control. We also heard from

ride-, drivers, that
gamification was noted by some

as detrimental to their physical
or psychological well-being such

as when they're locked into a
Quest they're struggling to

finish because rewards are "all
or nothing", increasing health
hazards of workers overworking.

talked about a heightened
awareness when driving at night.

One response drivers had for
this problem revolved around a

strong inclination towards
having more data driven insights

within the app. They suggested
how data analytics could improve

well-being, such as making
possible the creation of

balanced work schedules that
take into account the three
well-beings.

Here P23 and 21 are discussing
creating individualized plans

that allow them to know optimal
times to work and rest to not be

mentally stressed about meeting
their "bottom line" or financial

goals, suggesting how data
analytics can allow drivers to

plan more, avoid driving while
sleep-deprived, and encourage a

in a meaningful way to support
long term financial planning.

Drivers also felt they had to
forego physical and

psychological well-being while
working. They often felt

pressure to accept all rides
that came their way to maintain

high ratings on the platform.
But it meant things like risking

their physical safety and
exhaustion. Drivers talked about

concerns about carjackings, and
female drivers in particular

talked about a heightened
awareness when driving at night.

We heard early on during focus
groups that drivers didn't feel

their well-being was supported
by platforms. For example, "Uber

discourages you from taking that
long view of the past month or

the past few previous months. It
does remain very weekly

focused." Here, P11 indicates
that financial well-being was

impacted by platforms
structuring work statistics in a

way that prevents drivers from
understanding their performance

in a meaningful way to support
long term financial planning.

We structured our findings into
four problems that we identified

drivers discussed and the
solutions they came up with to

address these, through thematic
analysis. And we'll discuss a
subset of these.

to share their perceptions of
platform fairness.

From focus groups and
interviews, we constructed

participatory design workshop
with workers to design solutions

that they envisioned for
improving their own well-being.

In these workshops, we created a
structure to support workers in

designing solutions. First, we
displayed one of five prompts

about a driving scenario, which
was created and informed by

focus groups and interviews.
Then we asked workers questions

to probe how they believe
platform algorithms to work as

well as their algorithmic
imaginaries --- which is how

they envisioned the algorithm
should work to support them ---

to help them start thinking
about and sharing their
experiences.

Next, we assigned gig workers to
an intervention so they could

consider the prompt through this
lens and imagine how a solution

could be designed to fulfill
their needs. The five prompts

covered the five principles for
fair labor platform design, and

the three intervention types
reflected the types of apps and

social media forums that drivers
currently use for their work.

The final outcome wasn't to
design the three interventions

in depth, but to use all of this
to generate solutions and

analyze the types of solutions
drivers came up with.

algorithmic management for their
well-being?

We held focus groups,
interviews, and workshops with

24 unique driver participants.
We held initial focus groups and

interviews with drivers to
understand how algorithmic

management impacts their
well-being, defining it as the

following: physical,
psychological and financial

well-being based on the
Partnership on AI's Framework

for Promoting Workforce
Well-Being in the AI-Integrated
Workplace.

In focus groups and interviews,
we incorporated the use of

pairwise comparisons in order to
discuss why drivers preferred

certain rides over others, and
understand how these features of

the rides impact their
well-being. We also asked them

to share their perceptions of
platform fairness.

organizes, coordinates, and even
evaluates workers.

Given the pervasiveness of gig
work with as many as 55 million

Americans participating in some
form in 2017, research has

focused on understanding how
algorithmic management impacts

workers, as well as how they
react to it. A specific focus

though on how algorithmic
management impacts worker

well-being has been less
explored. Thus two questions

driving our study were 1) how
does algorithmic management

affect the well-being of gig
workers? And 2) what designs or

solutions do gig workers have
around how to improve

algorithmic management for their
well-being?

Alexander Boltz, Chun-Wei Wang,
and Min Kyung Lee.

Algorithmic management refers to
the practice where rather than

human managers. workers are
managed by software algorithms

or automated platforms. The gig
economy in particular ---

encompassing short term,
on-demand work, such as

rideshare drivers, freelance
contractors, and so on --- has

been subject to algorithmic
management that manages,

organizes, coordinates, and even
evaluates workers.

Angie: Our paper is called
Algorithmic Management

Reimagined for Workers and By
Workers: Centering Worker

Well-Being In Gig Work. This is
the work of Angie Zhang,

Alexander Boltz, Chun-Wei Wang,
and Min Kyung Lee.
